summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary sworn interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General with a Federal Bureau of Prisons correctional officer lieutenant (SIS Lieutenant) regarding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York City. The interview covers the lieutenant's investigation into Epstein's first suicide attempt in July 2019, the circumstances leading up to his death on August 10, 2019, including failures in cellmate assignment, rounds and counts, camera malfunctions, and other security lapses.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found with a noose in his SHU cell. His cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, alerted officers. The SIS Lieutenant's investigation was inconclusive; Epstein stated he did not try to harm himself and that Tartaglione did not harm him. Epstein was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Moved to Psych Observation
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch and placed in psychological observation.

events.title: Epstein Returned to SHU
events.description: Epstein was removed from psych observation and placed back in the SHU with a requirement to have a cellmate.

events.title: Camera System Stopped Recording
events.description: The MCC's camera system stopped recording. This was not discovered until August 8.

events.title: Cameras Discovered Down
events.description: The witness and Associate Warden N'diaye discovered the cameras were not recording while trying to review footage. They notified Ronald Monk and Captain Petrucci. Monk said he would work overtime to fix them.

events.title: Tartaglione Transferred; Epstein Left Without Cellmate
events.description: Inmate Nicholas Tartaglione was transferred out of MCC (listed as WAB - With All Belongings), not taken to court as initially believed. He was escorted out by Officer John Mccoy, who also brought Epstein down for an attorney visit. No notification was made up the chain of command that Epstein was left without a cellmate, a known requirement.

events.title: Epstein's Unsecured Phone Call
events.description: Unit Manager William Barr provided Epstein with an unsecured phone call in the SHU shower area. Epstein said he was calling his mother, but a male answered when Barr called to verify the number. This was a security violation.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Found Deceased
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found deceased in his SHU cell at MCC. Officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas were among the first responders. The witness was called in around 6:00 a.m. and began collecting evidence.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York City
keyFacts: The SIS Lieutenant's investigation into Epstein's first suicide attempt in July 2019 was inconclusive. Epstein denied trying to harm himself and said his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, did not harm him.

Multiple systemic failures contributed to Epstein's death: his required cellmate was transferred without replacement, mandatory rounds and counts were likely not performed, and the camera system had been offline since July 29, unbeknownst to staff until August 8.

On August 9, the day before his death, Epstein was provided an unsecured, unmonitored phone call by his unit manager, a serious security violation. The number he called was supposedly for his mother (who was deceased), and a male answered when the manager called to verify it.
Key staff, including the captain and an associate warden, were verbally notified on August 8 that the cameras were down and a memo was written, but the system was not repaired before Epstein's death.

The witness believes the primary responsibility for failing to ensure Epstein had a cellmate on August 9 lies with Officer John Mccoy, who escorted the cellmate out, and the SHU officers who should have notified supervisors, as well as the operations lieutenants who had access to the court list showing the cellmate was leaving (WAB).
